For information about setting up SSL on IIS, see http://www.iis.net/learn/manage/configuring-security/how-to-set-up-ssl-on-iis
 For information about the FormsAuthentication.RequireSSL property, see http://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/library/system.web.security.formsauthentication.requiressl.aspx
li: Configure IIS to use SSL/TLS. Get a valid certificate. Hosting service providers often sell valid SSL certificates. Install the certificate. Create an HTTPS binding for the site. A link in the "Additional Resources" section describes how to do this in detail.

Enable requireSSL for Forms Authentication. If your application uses Forms Authentication, edit the Web.config and set the requireSSL attribute to true for the authentication element, like so: <authentication mode="Forms" requiressl="true"></authentication>

Enable SSL for all pages. It's recommended to enable SSL/TLS for the entire site. Use the IIS Manager to require SSL for the entire site. The detailed instructions on how to do this are linked to at the bottom of this page.
For information about setting up SSL on IIS, see http://www.iis.net/learn/manage/configuring-security/how-to-set-up-ssl-on-iis
For information about the FormsAuthentication.RequireSSL property, see http://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/library/system.web.security.formsauthentication.requiressl.aspx
p: Use SSL/TLS to protect the authentication process.
Sensitive data, such as usernames, passwords, hashes, and keys has to be transmitted during authentication. The communication channel should be encrypted to prevent this data from being intercepted.
ol:
Configure IIS to use SSL/TLS. Get a valid certificate. Hosting service providers often sell valid SSL certificates. Install the certificate. Create an HTTPS binding for the site. A link in the "Additional Resources" section describes how to do this in detail.
 Enable requireSSL for Forms Authentication. If your application uses Forms Authentication, edit the Web.config and set the requireSSL attribute to true for the authentication element, like so: <authentication mode="Forms" requiressl="true"></authentication>
 Enable SSL for all pages. It's recommended to enable SSL/TLS for the entire site. Use the IIS Manager to require SSL for the entire site. The detailed instructions on how to do this are linked to at the bottom of this page.

html:
Applies To

  • ASP.NET

What to Do

Use SSL/TLS to protect the authentication process.

Why

Sensitive data, such as usernames, passwords, hashes, and keys has to be transmitted during authentication. The communication channel should be encrypted to prevent this data from being intercepted.

How

To protect authentication using SSL/TLS:

  1. Configure IIS to use SSL/TLS. Get a valid certificate. Hosting service providers often sell valid SSL certificates. Install the certificate. Create an HTTPS binding for the site. A link in the "Additional Resources" section describes how to do this in detail.
  2. Enable requireSSL for Forms Authentication. If your application uses Forms Authentication, edit the Web.config and set the requireSSL attribute to true for the authentication element, like so: <authentication mode="Forms" requiressl="true"></authentication>
  3. Enable SSL for all pages. It's recommended to enable SSL/TLS for the entire site. Use the IIS Manager to require SSL for the entire site. The detailed instructions on how to do this are linked to at the bottom of this page.

Additional Resources

  • For information about setting up SSL on IIS, see http://www.iis.net/learn/manage/configuring-security/how-to-set-up-ssl-on-iis
  • For information about the FormsAuthentication.RequireSSL property, see http://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/library/system.web.security.formsauthentication.requiressl.aspx
